Line 22: Line 22:  
In addition to cross-cultural differences in understanding love, ideas about love have also changed greatly over time. Some historians date modern conceptions of romantic love to courtly Europe during or after the Middle Ages, although the prior existence of romantic attachments is attested by ancient love poetry.<ref>[http://www.TrueOpenLove.org/reference/AncientLovePoetry.html Ancient Love Poetry]</ref>
 
In addition to cross-cultural differences in understanding love, ideas about love have also changed greatly over time. Some historians date modern conceptions of romantic love to courtly Europe during or after the Middle Ages, although the prior existence of romantic attachments is attested by ancient love poetry.<ref>[http://www.TrueOpenLove.org/reference/AncientLovePoetry.html Ancient Love Poetry]</ref>
    −
Because of the complex and abstract nature of love, discourse on love is commonly reduced to a [[thought-terminating cliché]], and there are a number of common [[proverb]]s regarding love, from [[Virgil]]'s "Love conquers all" to [[The Beatles]]' "[[All You Need is Love|All you need is love]]." [[Bertrand Russell]] describes love as a condition of "absolute value," as opposed to [[relative value]]. Theologian [[Thomas Jay Oord]] said that to love is to "act intentionally, in sympathetic response to others, to promote overall well-being." Philosopher [[Gottfried Leibniz]] said that love is "to be delighted by the happiness of another."<ref>[http://la.wikisource.org/wiki/Confessio_philosophi Gottfried Leibniz, ''Confessio philosophi''. Wikisource edition, retrieved Mar 25, 2009.]</ref>
+
Because of the complex and abstract nature of love, discourse on love is commonly reduced to a [[thought-terminating cliché]], and there are a number of common [[proverb]]s regarding love, from [[Virgil|Virgil's]] "[[Love Conquers All|Love conquers all]]" to the [[The Beatles|Beatles']] "[[All You Need is Love|All you need is love]]." [[Bertrand Russell]] describes love as a condition of "absolute value," as opposed to [[relative value]]. Theologian [[Thomas Jay Oord]] said that to love is to "act intentionally, in sympathetic response to others, to promote overall well-being."{{Fact}} Philosopher [[Gottfried Leibniz]] said that love is "to be delighted by the happiness of another."<ref>[http://la.wikisource.org/wiki/Confessio_philosophi Gottfried Leibniz, ''Confessio philosophi''. Wikisource edition, retrieved Mar 25, 2009.]</ref>
